channel.title: BBC News - World
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Afghanistan: Don't recognise Taliban regime, resistance urges
item.description: The all-men interim cabinet includes names of people on the US and UN most-wanted lists.

item.title: António Guterres says Taliban need UN's humanitarian aid
item.description: In return, the new regime must provide conditions for the UN to work in Afghanistan, secretary general tells BBC.

item.title: Paris attacks: Historic day of reckoning for night of terror
item.description: Survivors and families attend the long-awaited trial of 20 men accused of the deadly 2015 attacks.

item.title: Flooding hits Mexico hospital, killing 17 patients
item.description: A river bursts its banks in the town of Tula, cutting power and oxygen at the facility, officials say.

item.title: Britney Spears' father formally files to end conservatorship
item.description: Jamie Spears files papers in an LA court to formally end the 13-year arrangement with the singer.

item.title: Indonesia prison fire: Tangerang jail blaze kills 41 inmates
item.description: All of the dead, including two foreigners, were inmates, with guards unable to unlock doors in time.

item.title: Mexico decriminalises abortion in landmark ruling
item.description: The Supreme Court rules that prosecuting women for terminating pregnancies is unconstitutional.

item.title: Climate change: Vulnerable nations call for 'emergency pact'
item.description: The countries at greatest risk say all nations must take bigger steps to avoid climate catastrophe.

item.title: Australia media can be sued for social media comments, court rules
item.description: A landmark court ruling finds news outlets can be sued for comments posted on their social media.

item.title: Mexico: Powerful earthquake hits Acapulco
item.description: The magnitude-seven quake was felt strongly around 370 km away in Mexico City.

item.title: Hong Kong: Tiananmen vigil organisers arrested
item.description: Members of a pro-democracy organisation have been detained under a controversial security law.

item.title: Boeing: Directors to face investor lawsuit over fatal crashes
item.description: Shareholders can sue Boeing over claims it ignored safety warnings about its 737 Max plane, a US judge rules.

item.title: Bitcoin crashes on first day as El Salvador's legal tender
item.description: Technological glitches plagued the first day of El Salvador accepting Bitcoin as legal tender.

item.title: Somali feminist: Facebook is being used to silence me
item.description: Hanna Paranta has faced assassination attempts and now online attacks for helping abused women.

item.title: The Taliban embrace social media: 'We too want to change perceptions'
item.description: Famed for their shunning of technology, the Taliban are realising they need to be on social media too.

item.title: Nizar Banat: The death shaking the Palestinian leadership
item.description: The killing of Nizar Banat in Palestinian custody has fuelled rare protests calling for change.

item.title: India jewellery ad starring trans model wins hearts
item.description: The ad is being praised in India where popular culture still portrays transgender people as caricatures.

item.title: The South African farm turning flies into food for pets - and maybe people
item.description: A South African company is aiming to take advantage of a new interest in protein-rich insects.

item.title: Why coders love the AI that could put them out of a job
item.description: Artificial intelligence is getting better at penning code but still a long way from working alone.

item.title: Sebastian Vettel on speaking out as an LGBTQ+ ally: 'Everyone has the same right to love'
item.description: Sebastian Vettel made headlines at the Hungarian Grand Prix by wearing a T-shirt in support of LGBTQ+ rights. He tells the BBC's LGBT Sport Podcast why he is taking a stand.

item.title: Taliban fire shots to disperse protest in Kabul
item.description: Hundreds of protesters took to the streets on Tuesday to demand women's rights and denounce Taliban rule.

item.title: Australian bush rescue: Mother's reunion with boy lost for four days
item.description: Three-year-old Anthony "AJ" Elfalak is recovering with family after going missing for four days.

item.title: Mexico: Flash flooding sweeps away cars after heavy rain
item.description: Heavy rain in central Mexico sparked flash floods in Ecatepec and Nexahualcóyotl.

item.title: Esports: Why are there so few professional women gamers?
item.description: There are no female players in the top 300 earners in esports, according to research shared with BBC News.

item.title: Israeli conjoined twins see each other for first time after surgery
item.description: The Israeli twin girls were joined at the head but have been separated after a rare operation.

item.title: Chaos and confusion: The frenzied final hours of the Afghan government
item.description: Through interviews with insiders, BBC News has pieced together an account of how Afghanistan’s government unravelled.

item.title: Afghanistan: The pledge binding al-Qaeda to the Taliban
item.description: The history of the complex relationship between the two groups.

item.title: Afghanistan: Taliban accused of killing pregnant police officer
item.description: The killing comes amid increasing reports of escalating repression of women in Afghanistan.

item.title: US Senator Lindsey Graham: 'We will be going back into Afghanistan'
item.description: Republican Senator Lindsey Graham believes there will be no choice as "the threat will be so large".

item.title: Afghanistan: Rural areas welcome peace and end of war
item.description: In more rural areas of Afghanistan, people welcome the end of a war that has killed tens of thousands.
